Search for recipes of patsa, πατσά, a greek tripe soup.
The recipe is boiling for minutes to hours, depending on the stomach, goat, sheep, cow with water and salt, strain after the first 10 mins, cont. boiling.
When boiling is finished take the stomach out and cut it into small pieces.
Put pieces in with the juices. Serve in soup plates with raw garlic on the side, a drip of vinegar in each plate and a shitload of black pepper.

Ingredients for meringue soup for tripe

1 kg of beef - for example, brisket plus neck
2.5 liters of water - 2500 ml
2 medium or larger carrots - about 280 g
about 15 cm of leek - up to 150 g
a piece of celery root - about 100 g
1 parsley root - about 120 g
spices: 1 teaspoon salt, half a flat teaspoon pepper

Other ingredients for tripe

1 kg of beef tripe - flaked or sliced
3 cloves of garlic - about 15 g
Spices and herbs: 3 full tablespoons of marjoram; 4 grains of allspice; 2 bay leaves; one flat teaspoon each of ground ginger and nutmeg; half a teaspoon each of hot and sweet paprika; salt and pepper - dosed at the end

Ingredients for roux - can be omitted

5 tablespoons of wheat flour - up to 70 g
5 tablespoons of butter - up to 80 g

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I usually make fried rice with chicken, chinese bbq pork, egg, onion, peas and carrots. Marinate chicken with a little soy sauce and shaoxing wine then fry it up and set aside. Then fry onion until it's given up most of the moisture and add a little garlic and set aside. Next fry the rice (I like peanut oil best for this dish) and add all the ingredients back plus some salt pepper and a little more soy sauce. I use high heat for the chicken to get some color on it then turn it down to medium high for the rest.

>>18905894
Most important thing with fried rice is you wanna have all your ingredients ready to go, everything chopped and prepped ahead of time cuz the best fried rice is cooked fast. This includes the protein. I usually cook the egg and meat right before but Ieftover stuff is fine too.

I use a wok on a shitty electric coil stove on high heat, season with peanut oil, start with shallot or onion, carrot, garlic (sometimes ginger) until the carrots are tender. I add in the meat component at this point to warm it up (spam most often, but I've also done rotisserie chicken or strips of beef) then the rice goes in. I try and spread the rice around with as much direct contact with the wok as possible, leave it for a min or so to get crispy, then start tossing the rice on very high heat. After a few minutes of tossing, I make a well and add sambal chili sauce and fry it a bit. Add scallion whites and toss. At this point I taste it, add MSG, salt, pepper, soy sauce, oyster sauce, sesame oil and toss. Taste again and adjust seasoning, toss, serve with chopped green onion and sesame seeds.

posts.com:
>>18908544
Put your empty pan on high heat and let it get hot. Add in some canola/vegetable/peanut oil, anything with a high smoke point and let it coat the entire surface of the pan. Bring up the temp and when the oil starts to smoke, remove than pan from the heat and let it cool down a bit. Use a paper towel to remove any excess oil and you're ready to go. You just got a thin layer of oil to polymerize itself onto the steel and it will now act as a non stick barrier. If you did it right you will be able to crack an egg into your stainless pan with no additional oil and it will slide around on the cooking surface with no effort.

>>18908575

posts.com:
I think the big thing is cooking in batches with each type of ingredient done individually. Do your aromatics if you want em, meat, etc. then rice. I typically add egg while doing rice with half the pan separated. I usually prefer a smaller curd, like near risotto style created by stirring it into the rice while still raw.
For the rice, use a decent amount of oil, let that get hot and dump rice in. I use day old rice because in my experience it is much easier to deal with and gives you a better texture. Its not 100% necessary but it should be.
Let it sit for like 1-2 minutes then start stirring it up. Add butter and your dry shit like Salt, Onion Powder (if you don't use onions, its a requirement imo) Pepper, MSG, and Sugar (all to taste. Stir that up until rice is done heating up. Add your other shit to it and let the flavors get to know each other for a minute or two, then ring around the pan with soy sauce and mix it in. Not too much, many people overdue it with the soy sauce and it turns your rice mushy. Finish with the tiniest drizzle of sesame oil and its basically on par with hibachi.
I got my method from watching like hundreds of hibachi videos on youtube and asking some myself for their recipes they use. Its obviously different at home since you cant get that amount of heat

This video is a good place to start:

I don't think you want to make your own spaghetti from scratch for the first time, you'll have enough work to do between the meatballs and sauce. I personally wouldn't make the meatballs as large as him and I'd throw in some spices as well (oregano, ground fennel, basil, etc.).

This recipe might be better, although he surprisingly doesn't use any pork: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aBQ7Q1INJhk

Be careful not to overwork Italian meatballs as that makes they more rubbery. Italian meatballs should be tender. Swedish meatballs can take more agitation to become a bit springy.

Meatballs freeze well. Make a big batch, freeze some, and you'll have them on hand for weeknight pasta, soup, pizza toppings, sandwiches, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Meatballs
>Chop garlic and herbs
>Add to bowl with whatever mince you're using (beef/pork/venison/lamb)
>Season with salt and pepper (Worcestershire optional)
>Mix by hand then shape into balls
>Pre bake them or brown them lightly in the pan you'll be making the sauce in
Pasta
>Make dough
>Roll it out
>Cut
>Drape over something and allow it to dry a bit
>Boil in salted water
Tomato sauce
>Soak tomatoes in boiling water so they're easy to peel
>Saute onion and garlic (carrot, capsicum, celery are up to you)
>Add some dried herbs
>Add diced tomatoes
>Season
>Add some red wine
>Let it simmer and reduce a bit
>Add meatballs and cook with the lid off until the sauce consistency is to your liking
>Take off the heat and stir through fresh basil
>Serve meatballs and sauce over spaghetti
>Grate over parmesan
Wala.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So all good meatballs will contain breadcrumbs. The best piece of advice I could give you is to use panko breadcrumbs and to soak them in onion juice for 10mins before combining.

Most recipes will say to include onion and breadcrumbs.. but if you take the onion and grate it with a micograter - it turns into a puree and will expand the breadcrumbs BEFORE you cook the meatballs.

It means the meatballs will be extra juicy and won't fall apart (as the breadcrumbs won't expand as they are cooking as they have already absorbed the moisture).

Hope that helps!

Ugh. This morning I had 65g left of one coffee. Normally I use 50g per cup. My hand grinder fits 45g in the hopper and 50g in the catch cup. No problem, I can dump halfway. Well, I waited too long to dump the catch cup. The force of the grounds pushed the magnetic catch cup off the grinder and spilled the coffee to the floor.

Fuck it, right? It's my house. I swept up the grounds onto a piece of paper with a paintbrush. Not using the broom–I know what the broom's been in. I recovered 60g. Yes, there was hair in there. Yes, there appeared to be some sand and dirt. But those aren't going through the paper filter. Anyway, pourover brewed as normal. Resulting cup is MORE delicious than usual.

What has happened?

Scenario 1: my floor dirt is fucking delicious.
Scenario 2: increased coffee to water ratio is better (this is not ideal because it means more money)
Scenario 3: The floor has sieved the finer fines out of my grounds giving me a cleaner cup (also not ideal because I'll be tempted to waste coffee)

>load basket with grounds and tamp down tightly to about half full
>put moka pot on full heat electric hot plate
That's it. It's extremely consistent. If I want more solids in the drink or a stronger pull then I can grind finer or fill more of the basket.

I think a gas range makes it harder because it's harder to heat the base evenly. I was also getting gross cups from mine for a long while and that included looking up methods. When I do the greentext I know I'm getting similar brew times and temps. It makes a sweet easy cup. Tamping probably discourages solids from traveling to the final cup and in theory maybe lowers channeling.

>>18913195
>>18913183
Anon, as a followup since you may not see this until later: excessively bitter flavors frequently come from overextraction which means you might be brewing your coffee too long. You should consider grinding coarser without changing any other variables and see if that makes a difference. If using espresso, consider pulling a shorter shot without changing grind size or grind coarser to get a faster shot. Either way, the extraction of the beans will be less. Another possibility is that the water temperature may be too high which causes more efficient extraction of bitter compounds in coffee. If varying grind size doesn't solve your issue, consider lowering the water temperature 3-5 degrees or so to see if you move in a good direction and continue until you reach where you want to be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18913337
No guarantees this will solve your issue but a broad rule of thumb is that harsh bitter flavors are from overextraction and harsh acidity is from underextraction. If acidity and bitterness are both balanced and there's a pleasant almost sweet taste from the espresso then you're right where you want to be. A general rule of thumb is to get your desired amount of coffee out in approximately 30s, which is a surprisingly long time if you're not used to it. If you want 2:1 (30g espresso out for 15g of coffee in) you may need to grind quite fine. If you find your shots are running quick, then you may need to settle for luongo shots at a 3 or 4:1 ratio until you can dial in your grind for more conventional 1.5-2.5 espresso ratios.

Temperature defects are tough to deal with because typically only really high-end machines will have custom temperature settings. Hoffman says that temp defects are typically not that severe compared to extraction defects so grind size and its effect on shot timing are more important.

Another factor a lot of lower-end machines run into is channeling because the pumps run at too high of pressure. You end up with underextracted and overextracted areas which creates the worst of both worlds. Adding a puck screen in forces even flow over the puck and if your machine is modifiable with an lower-pressure OPV spring (9 bar is considered standard) then I would recommend making that modification because it's easy and cheap to do. My Gaggia runs at 15 bar stock which is way too high, the 9 bar spring will set that as the new upper limit.

posts.com:
1kg flour
800g (about 5) potatoes mashed
400g butter
50g salt
3 egg yolks
150ml milk
two packets dry yeast.
boil peel and mash the potatoes. yeast goes in the milk with some sugar. flour butter and potatoes combine, and the yeast and milk, yolks, let it mix a minute, add the salt. knead that shit, refrigerate for an hour, roll out 2cm thick, separate into rolls, let rise, brush with egg, bake 200c
>my faggot breadmaker can't fit 2kg of ingredients

>so that should make it much quicker to recoup the cost of the breadmaker
i'll break down the math for you. let's be generous and assume we don't buy $1.75 store brand garbage bread but instead we buy something decent like farmhouse for $4. let's also buy our bread ingredients in bulk to bring the cost of each loaf made down to $1. we save at best $3/loaf so you're payoff time is going to come down to how much bread you actually go through. if you have a family and couple of kids so maybe you go through 2 loaves a week at which point you have a yearly savings of $312/year. that saving can buy you a very nice bread machine and you will get your money back by the end of a year. for me, the savings is only half of that because i only go through one loaf per week at best. do i really want to invest $2-300 if it's going to take me multiple years to break even? meh, guess it depends if i want to pick up a new hobby.

The one i make myself, just a simple vinegar based sauce.

50g Scotch bonnets, 120g generic red chillies for flavour not heat, half a small onion, 3 cloves of garlic, 240ml apple cider vinegar, 5g salt. Chop all of it and add everything to a sauce pan, simmer for 10 minutes, let cool slightly then add to a blender untill smooth.

>>18913140
Yes, here you go. I gotta sleep now. Later.

How to make rice:
1. Weigh rice on scale note weight.
2. Rinse rice with copious amounts of room temp to cold water until water runs semi clear to clear. The more the better
3. Place rice in bowl and cover with 2-3 inches of filtered water. Wait 30 minutes or until rice appears opaque and crumbles easily when pressed between fingers.
4. Drain rice by placing in a strainer and let stand in strainer for 25 minutes.
5. Place equal parts rice and filtered water in a high walled pot. Cover rice.
6. Put heat on max temp and start a timer.
7. Once steam starts coming out of pot or water starts boiling turn heat to 2-3 or very low and cook for how long it took to reach boil.
8. Once time is up turn off heat and let sit for 15 minutes without touching.
9. Fluff rice with plastic or wooden rice scoop. Serve.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18905181
Did you boil your brine/vinegar before pouring it in your mason jar? I find that doing that and routinely flipping the jar while it is cooling helps reduce potential mold growth.
Post pictures of the fuzzy. Although it's very NOT recommended, I've salvaged a moldy jar before. When I first noticed a bit of white fuzz inside the jar near the lid I trashed anything above the brine surface and dumped the submerged eggs in a bowl, and rinsed them in hot tap water multiple times to remove any residue from the jar. Ate them promptly for lunch and I was fine. Most mold doesn't like vinegar due to the acidity, so the likelihood of it reaching below into the brine and tainting eggs if you catch it quickly is low.
Of course, that is a risk I was willing to take and is not recommended.

>>18900636
>Could I still gong fu brew it with a gawain like
A cheap porcelain gaiwan is all you really need. Yixing maybe makes a slight difference but it is not work worrying about when starting out.

>If i keep the boxes I have closed and outside of light they should last a long time right?
Those teas should be fine indefinitely if they came sealed up well. You could stick the boxes in a ziplock bags for additional protection if you want. How did the tea come stored in the boxes?

>>18900733
>Is an electric kettle with a temperature setting where it can keep the water at a certain temp necessary?
For puerh boiling or just off boiling water is what is typically used. An electric kettle that you can set to lower temperatures is nice for green tea and being able to keep the water hot is convenient but you don't need one starting out.

Shouldn't be too hard to just find it loose on it's own, honeybush is good too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18880148
I opened up my first 2018 Taetea V93 tuo tonight. Bought it on Amazon via the official store for pretty cheap. $35.99 USD for 500g.
It pried open easily, despite feeling more compressed than the typical DaYi cake. I've been enjoying it all night. Not in any particularly scientific way, but just enjoying it casually as I would for a daily drinker like I'm hoping this to be.
The first few brews are solid. It's mild and earthy flavor with a hint of roasted nuts. Maybe a little flat to a fault, but it could also be the recent transport through a damn cold winter. I also inexplicably brewed it with a little less material than I usually do. Either way, the flavors of the tea are what you'd expect from a shou of its age, but dialed back compared to a 7572.
From the smell of the leaves, perhaps there's just a little bit of sweetness trying to come out that I haven't found yet. Been playing around 190-200 degrees F.
Not a bad tea at all! Given the price and shipping availability from Amazon, I could see it being a daily work beater. Given the nice little 100g tuos it comes as, it's also the tea I would give to friends getting into the hobby.

>>18912197
The sign is a subtle joke. The shop is called "Sneed's Feed & Seed", where feed and seed both end in the sound "-eed", thus rhyming with the name of the owner, Sneed. The sign says that the shop was "Formerly Chuck's", implying that the two words beginning with "F" and "S" would have ended with "-uck", rhyming with "Chuck". So, when Chuck owned the shop, it would have been called "Chuck's Fuck and Suck".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
That's it. I'm sick of all this "Masterwork German Knight" bullshit that's going on in the cooking culture right now. Japanese knives deserve much better than that. Much, much better than that.

I should know what I'm talking about. I myself commissioned a genuine Japanese knife in Japan for 2,400,000 Yen (that's about $20,000) and have been practising with it for almost 2 years now. I can even cut slabs of solid prime cut with my knife.

Japanese smiths spend years working on a single knife and fold it up to a million times to produce the finest blades known to mankind.

Japanese knives are thrice as sharp as European swords and thrice as hard for that matter too. Anything a French knife can cut through, a Japanese knife can cut through better. I'm pretty sure a Japanese knife could easily bisect a cow wearing full plate with a simple vertical slash.

Ever wonder why medieval Europe never bothered conquering Japan? That's right, they were too scared to fight the disciplined sushi chefs and their Japanese knives of destruction. Even in World War II, American soldiers targeted the men with the Japanese knives first because their killing power was feared and respected.

So what am I saying? Japanese knives are simply the best chef tool that the world has ever seen, and thus, require better stats in the d20 system. Here is the stat block I propose for Japanese knives:

(One-Handed Exotic Weapon)
1d12 Damage
19-20 x4 Crit
+2 to hit and damage
Counts as Masterwork

(Two-Handed Exotic Weapon)
2d10 Damage
17-20 x4 Crit
+5 to hit and damage
Counts as Masterwork

Now that seems a lot more representative of the cutting power of Japanese knives in real life, don't you think?

tl;dr = Japanese knives need to do more damage in cooking culture, see my new stat block.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I lived overseas you could buy all kinds of drugs by the gram/kilo/ton from the same place, for some reason they didn't care how much or little you bought.
I'm not entirely sure what everyone else did with the various products but I used to buy cannabis seeds by the kilo and I used them to bake bread and make popcorn. One day these taliban dudes came up to me and were like "why you always buy kilos of the seeds, you have no farm, we angry and not understand" and I invited them to my house and gave them a bunch of seedy bread.

These fuckers lost their shit, they got their phones out and were filming this bread and eating this bread crying laughing in some taliban tiktok. "we followed an American spy and found THIS". They quickly found that you didn't get high eating the bread, and "bread" isn't really a thing there and "wholemeal" is totally unknown to them.
From that day forward everyone in the market used to laugh at me and made exclamations like "He is the baker man" "420 baker snoop dog" and often made pantomimes of me baking- which they considered feminine/homosexual but also oddly intriguing and it was hotly debated if eating the useless weed seeds was degenerate or just stupid. Every week I would give these fuckers some kind of random food product like sharezade.

They also didn't understand my fascination with working "curd" and carrying around gallons of milk, and again there was often debate between locals if these alien foods were "permitted", "forbidden" or just strange. Nor did they understand "pasta" which they said tasted of nothing, or using two flatbreads to make a hamburger which they considered a distasteful kind of Turkish kebab. Most of these fuckers couldn't read of write and for this and other reasons their use of mobile phones was bizarre. It would be very common to just get a text of 6 smiley faces if someone wanted to see you, they used that shit like heiroplyphs and even the literate locals were fiend in Hajiglyphs

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Precision is the glass ceiling, if you don't use recipies, write notes and measure ingredients you will never improve. You will never survive in a commercial environment, you will never achieve greatness.

it's true that metric won't solve all your problems, but that's an excuse not an argument. There's a lot of things metric won't tell you (like the strength of cumin, how spicy a chilli is, what colour a sauce is) but that's like saying a hammer won't remove a screw- it's not what metric is for.

Without metric you hit this glass ceiling and can't work out why you're not progressing. you measure cumin by taste so can't work out how much you have or need in the pantry, you judge how much chilli to use by taste and can't portion it, you gaugue the colour of sauce by eye and are forever trapped starting will less and adding more last minute.
There are two kinds of family recipes, ones in metric that record how each generation made something; and "grandma showed me" recipes that are lost or destroyed in a single generation.

Home chefs also hit the glass ceiling when cooking becomes technical, when preserving they can't work out sugar syrup by weight/volume/ratio. When pickling they can't work out PH, when making cheese and custard they can't work out the temperature drop required to set the mix.
They hit the glass ceiling, adding double the sugar which is required as a buffer, adding double the acid, freezing things "overnight" or cooking them for an unreasonable period of time. Then they hit a big red barrier "do not attempt this unless you actually understand the science involved" and they angrily poison themselves.

Similar experience here. I tried the much-touted Subway roast beef sub. Supposedly, according to social media posts that were "totally genuine and not paid-for marketing", it was a good fast food item enjoyed by many.
I ordered the sandwich and received what appeared to be a disheveled wad of paper, perhaps something to toss in the refuse bin. However, I was assured that my supposedly tasty treat was inside.
I followed the instructions and, upon removing the many layers of questionable wrapping material, was met with what appeared to be a "food-related item" that suffered a tumble down a set of stairs before being stomped under a steel toe boot.
Now, I'm not one to decry fast food presentation differing from advertisements, they all do it. But this seemed to be crossing the line. Nevertheless, I knew that presentation wasn't everything, so I carried on. I picked up the scrambled mass and, upon bringing it to my mouth, was hit with a pungent aroma that seemed to seat itself in the back of my sinus. Tears welled in my eyes as I opened my mouth and took my first (and only) bite. I tasted nothing upon entry. I tasted nothing upon the first bite of the chew. I chewed thrice more before "flavor" made itself known. It was not a welcome one. I have never had the displeasure of chewing on an old dishrag that had been dropped and forgotten behind a restaurant dishwasher, but this must have been its closest "edible" imitation.
I let the chewed mass fall from my mouth, back into the so-called "wrapper", letting it dribble upon the supposed "sandwich". I went to the nearest drug store and bought mouth wash - it took 5 cycles to rinse out the taste. Unfortunately, the pungent aroma that had seated itself in my sinus would persist for hours.

It was not until I stopped at my local Arby's restaurant and ordered a Roast Beef Sandwich that I had would have a sandwich worthy of the day. And a much-enjoyed one, at that. I highly recommend everyone try Arby's Roast Beef.

Get a gravity one. Get a good brand like Berkel, small diameter blade (size of the blade decides a lot of the cost and it's irrelevant at home). Look at second hand/auction sites and be quick, professional butchers are hawking them 24/7 for good reason, these things last decades.

Don't buy cheap garbage though. Your meats will come out shrivelled, your onions soggy, your cheeses mushy and torn. They're hell to clean and a recipe for accidents.

>>18877773
I came up with the idea for Peat Monster, nice to see it mentioned here. The first batch was a 50/50 blend of Caol Ila and Clynelish (or maybe Ardmore, it was a long time ago lol), both about 10 or 15 years old, aged in ex-bourbon, and bottled at cask strength. It was just called Monster. John Glaser, the founder, didn’t want to make it at first because he didn’t personally enjoy peaty whisky. It turned out to be the blend that put him on the map, so he decided to make it regular production item as Peat Monster, with some water added to lower the proof.

>>18899502
you've gone about it wrong from the start if you thought cheap flavored whiskey would be easier to drink or be free of the quality's of ethanol and how it affects your body.

first learn how to drink(approach it like a hot beverage or soup, less is more, savor it for as long as you can muster and do not do shots). then find what you like to drink(better to have 2 or more bottles poured at once to compare and find your sweetspot). then you combine those aspects and become all that is man(who can appreciate the glass in his hand as well as the drink within).

if you're only looking for inebriation then go down the buttchug path.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18905344
something from Caol Ila, but not bottled by Diageo. so basically any Islay single malt that is branded but never names the distillery is 9/10 times Caol Ila and usually about 1/2 the price of the officially bottled 12 and with better representation of the malt.

in terms of overall taste, Kilchoman Machir Bay is very similar to Ardbeg 10 in my experience, but I enjoy Kilchoman more. it sounds cheesey but you can taste the integrity of the farm-to-bottle aspect in Kilchoman. richer and oilier than Ardbeg without the industrial edge. Machir Bay is usually 5-7 years old with a small amount of sherry maturation, but it tastes like 10 year old whisky where as Ardbeg 10 tastes like younger whisky from less active casks.

If you find a bottle of The 6 Isles, that will be a good adjacent pour. if not that then Ledaig 10. recent batches have been more/less sherried so pay attention to the color if you arent crazy about that combination.

posts.com: Why do people say this place is good, and talk about it like it's an elevated experience compared to the other big burger chains? Why do they even like it? Wendy's is the nastiest fast food I've ever had, and I've tried almost everything on the menu. All their food lacks salt and is completely flavorless and bland, and usually it has a faint taste of bleach or some sort of cleaner. Even the burgers that look like they're supposed to have flavor like the baconator or the limited time specialty ones are all completely bland. The fries are soggy and limp and have a weird bitter flavor, and also don't have enough salt. And they leave the skin on which they try to pretend makes them more "rustic" or "healthy" which is completely fake. It's simply a cost cutting measure which REDUCES the flavor and texture. I believe that everyone who likes Wendy's is a complete fucking rube who let's a commercial inform his tastes. Because there's no way a person with a tongue independently came to the conclusion that any of this garbage is good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Oh and I tried the chicken sandwich and it was literally the worst chicken sandwich of any chain restaurant. The chicken was stringy and gristly and dry, like it was made from rooster breast, and it had pockets of artificially injected hot brine that burst out when I bit into the chicken like rancid pustules. The breading was shitty and soft, and the lettuce was limp and yellow, and it had NO SALT.

WHY THE FUCK DOES THIS RESTAURANT NOT KNOW WHAT SALT IS?

posts.name: The Blogposter
posts.com:
>>18905415
Had a Tinder date once that wanted to go to Wendy's as a first meet. Figured if nothing else I can get a chocolate shake, some fries, and enjoy a cheap meal and move on with my night even if all she was doing was extorting a meal out of me.

Turns out she paid for both of us since she asked us to go there. Okay, so she's a fair person and not extorting me at all, cool.
I got a couple fries, chocolate shake, not big into ordering meat from fast food in any form.
She gets some burger with two patties, bacon, a nice looking bun. Fries. Chili. Soda. Chocolate shake.
We sit down and we're chatting all sorts of shit, she had a good sense of humor, was pretty but awkward, pretty awesome gal desu.
I dipped a fry into my shake, delicious.
She dipped a fry into hers, delicious.
She then dipped a fry into her chili, okay awesome she's a dipper. I make a joke about dipping into her. She laughs.
She then dips a fry into her chili and then dips that into her chocolate shake.
Okay, that was weird. I can see bits of chili and cheese sitting on top of her melting chocolate shake.
Kinda disgusted but hell I was working as a crime scene clean up at the time so I'd seen worse.
She does it again and again. Her chocolate shake is basically half chili at this point.
We finish up, I ask if she wants to go for a walk down to the park and maybe skirt over to my place for a movie or something.
She says sure.
Throwing all my stuff out and I go to help her toss her trash, but she saves the chocolate chili shake and takes a huge ripping slurp of it. Watching the sludgy chili cheese drain into the bottom of her cup and slide into her straw and swish around her gums and teeth and splash at the back of her throat made me gag.

I told her I needed to leave, wasn't feeling well and was going to go lie down.
>Oh anon I can join you we can skip the park
Haha, no no, sorry, feeling sick really. Don't want you to catch it.

So that's my first and last experience with Wendy's enjoyers.

>>18905415
Wendy's food simply looks better. The bun has a colour and shine to it that implies a higher quality, the square patties have a recognizable aesthetic that separates them from a generic frozen patty, and the skin on fries look higher effort. My experience has always been the assembly is more consistent, the burgers less likely to be squished or poorly put together.

On top of this, they have items on the menu that imply more sophistication than BK or McDicks. The chili and baked potatoes gesture to actual, real cooking in a way that McDonalds and BK cannot.

I agree their larger burgers are bland and their chicken is awful, but I'd take their chili over anything else on offer at any national fast food chain for a side, I'd take a Frosty over any dessert a national chain offers, and I'd take a JBC over any value menu item other burger joints can toss at it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18907490
You have it backwards. Savory broadly describes foods that are tasty but not sweet or dessert-like. Savory foods can be salty, umami, and even bitter. Potato chips could be described as savory, for instance. Bacon is both salty and umami. Umami refers specifically to the meaty taste sensation of glutamates, regardless of the presence of salt or bitterness. It refers to something very specific and that justifies it having its own word.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911661
For this amount of rice, I'm using 1 single canned chipotle pepper in adobo sauce. A bit more than a tablespoon. You have to be careful, if you use too much it will be too spicy for most people.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911672
Rice, chipotle, a little bit of salt and oil go on high heat to start getting up to temp. The best way to make rice on a stovetop in my experience, is to get everything up to hot and boiling as fast as possible, and then seal it off to steam ASAP. Might as well heat up the rice before you add liquid.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911682
This was 1 cup of rice. I'm adding 0.75 cup of smoky pork/chicken stock, and 0.75 cup of water, for a ratio of 1:1.5 rice to liquid. If you can, bring the liquid to a boil before you measure it in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911690
As soon as it reaches a full boil...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18904130
Thanks for a good thread, Anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911699
...shut off the heat, and do whatever you can to close it up. Maybe don't attempt to seal it like a pressure cooker, but you want the least amount of steam escaping as possible.

Also, you want to leave the pot on the heat source. If you remove it, whatever cool surface you place it on will leech the heat from the pot and your rice may not cook thoroughly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911714
45 minutes later, rice should be finished. You can let it go longer if you have any doubts, it won't burn or anything. Fluff it with a fork and let it sit for 5-10 minutes. With this chipotle rice, normally I would add a bit of lime zest/juice and cilantro at this point, but I had none of that. It's still pretty good...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

...bottom of pot shown, nothing burnt or stuck. Perfectly cooked rice!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911759
Hard to tell but I eye-balled about 1.5 TBSP cornstarch, 1/2 cup sugar, and 1/2 cup white vinegar. I just like to eye-ball sauces... the only really important volume is the cornstarch. If making a cornstarch-based sauce, I would always do less than you think. You can always add more later, although it's important if you add cornstarch to a hot liquid, you must create a slurry first with cornstarch and cold water, other wise it will clump badly, and you will need a blender to fix it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911777
For cornstarch to activate as a thickener, you need to bring the sauce right up to a simmer. When you first add the cornstarch, it will make the sauce appear more opaque, and you can tell the sauce is ready because it will start to turn translucent again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911784
After letting the sauce cool for a bit, I zested some orange, lemon, and lime in and squeezed a bit of their juice. The reason I didn't do this before is because heat damages these flavors, this way it will taste more fresh and vibrant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18911790
Whisked together and done. This sauce came out really nice. I was shooting for something similar to sweet & sour sauce, with a slight bitterness from the citrus and I think I nailed it. Not too bitter, tangy, sweet, very citrusy.

The fact that someone can go to a chiropractor and say "ow!" when their arm bends a certain way, and then have the chiropractor say, "that's not normal; you should be able to bend your arm that way; you should probably see a doctor" is all it takes for the original analogy to work. Someone who has only eaten iodized salt their entire life is on par with someone who has never tried to touch their toes.

>for some reason
Your body uses your fat when it has no other way to gain energy. That's why the dude was able to go over a year without eating. You also didn't really need to have your vitals monitored frequently, maybe you should get a checkup once a week at the second week mark of the fast, but after that once a month should be fine. The reason it was necessary to get frequent checkups back then was because of how unprecedented it was and he needed to be sure he wasn't missing any essential minerals. Nowadays fatties fasting is pretty common and all you need is some basic research on what kind of supplements you need to take.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18910055
Genetics doesn't really work that way. If there's a unique gene idenified in mammoths that expresses in a particular way in vitro, or interacts in a rat model in an interesting way, then that might be worth the effort, as a scientific project, to splice into an elephant and see what that looks like. But only a small minority of genes work that way -- express one protein in isolation and that's basically it. The rest work as a mutually interacting system, moderated for one thing by the 3d structure of DNA itself (and that itself is shaped by the "junk" DNA, among other things).

So while it may be interesting and useful to look at a couple genes here and there, because new genes can be quite useful, that's not really telling you much about the mammoth itself. I'm not saying a fuller picture won't come together eventually, but a 5 year or 20 year timeline is ridiculous.

posts.com:
>>18910123
>It's not like fully understanding real mammoths is inherently useful to anything to begin with.
For one thing, it's part of human (pre)history, which makes it inherently interesting. For another, there are questions in the mammoth that are useful to our understanding of how megafauna adapt to a changing environment. Did climate change ultimately kill the mammoth? Why then couldn't they just migrate North to the arctic? Thermoregulation? Other animals seemed to have been able to shed their hair fairly quickly -- it's not too difficult an evolutionary step. Disease? Any old disease vulnerability would be useful to find out about. Lack of food would be the obvious, but again, they had a huge area over which to migrate. All this is relevant to how we manage megafauna today (an operation we spend a lot of money on, whether in zoos or wildlife parks or the hunting industry, or as climate change persists, in future de-extinction projects). There seems to be some agreement that there was a shitload of human hunting that mostly finished them off at least, so a genetics project won't tell us anything more about that.

In terms of cost-benefit I agree that it's mostly that people, both lay and scientist, are mostly interested in seeing an extinct, Ice Age creature come back to life a la Jurassic Park. But we spend a lot of money on science and exploration that's more about satisfying our curiosity and imagination than having direct or foreseeable-term applicability.

>>18906712
Well, vodka can be made from corn too but moonshine is still not vodka. The difference might surprise you. Vodka is a higher proof distillate than moonshine. In production it's made into a neutral spirit which is nearly pure ethanol, then it's proofed down with water. Moonshine doesn't have to be proofed down, hence its high proof from the bottle. It is, however, less thoroughly distilled in production compared to vodka, leaving you with less ethanol by volume due to other things being left in.

>>18906529
The original Mountain Dew wasn't the Mountain Dew of today. The post-prohibition whiskey mixer the Hartmans created was originally a generic lemon-lime soda like 7-Up that sold like shit. After more than a decade of mediocrity, eventually they started bottling a revised version of the citrus formula in 1960 that basically ripped off Sun Drop and used orange juice to give it that same kind of taste, and they called it Tri-City Lemonade. They began bottling Tri-City Lemonade in the Mountain Dew bottles with the hillbilly on it, and eventually it became a hit and Pepsi bought the brand and formula. They don't sell the original formula anymore, but the old Tri-Cities bottler that used to make Mountain Dew still sells the old citrus soda that overshadowed it at the time -- Dr. Enuf. It has a unique taste and was originally sold as a hangover cure alongside the old Mountain Dew mixers.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18911980
technically you never lose muscle mass; your muscles undergo cellular division during strenuous activity and create what are called myonuclei. These Myonuclei are like "hubs" for your muscle mass since each one is capped at how much mass it can put on. More myonuclei = more mass: when you "lose" mass, your myonuclei deflate/lose the muscle, but you never lose your myonuclei. You can regain the strength and gains of an entire 10 years of lifting after a period of inactivity in like 6-12 months granted to you train hard enough

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18908255
What I've found is to specifically source out the "thick cut" pork chops for more reliable cooking. Most of the supermarket thin cut chops end up like you said, easily overcooked and leathery due to how lean they're cut with virtually no fat in the muscle. They're so easy to overcook you have to baby them and watch them like a hawk or they overcook instantly.

I pretty much treat them as burgers, 2-3 minutes on each side on medium-high heat if they're fully defrosted at room temperature.

For the thick cut ones, I generally go 4-6 minutes depending on how thick, but it varies from cut to cut. I'll typically keep a probe thermometer handy and measure every 2 minutes or so to make sure I've got the right temperature lined up.

>>18908425
IIRC, if you add salt to processed meat (ground, schnitzel-pounded), it causes the meat to 'sweat' excessively during cooking (so it dries too much/quickly). This doesn't occur in whole meat chunks, because the fiber structure stops the osmotic effect from advancing past the surface layer. Said structure is destroyed when mechanically processing the piece.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18910802
The twenty dollar rice cookers are fantastic. And instant pot/pressure cooker would also be a good investment. You can do everything with these appliances with a few pots. Take your time learning to make meals and there's no rush. Learning to make rice in a pot is a good idea anyways.

The best way to look at healthy low cost cooking, imho, is:
>fiber
>nutrients
>proteins

Simply put, learn to cook lots of vegetables for fiber and nutrients. Then have a big fatty piece of meat with this. Then you can shop the sales and stay out of the processed foods aisles. Assuming you have a freezer you can buy large amounts of on sale protein and freeze it in meal sized amounts to thaw later. Pressure cookers don't need thawing if you go that way.

Write out of list of foods you like to eat and think through if they are healthy enough or how to make them healthier. I like pork sausage or bratwurst. By itself or with a lot of simple carbohydrates it's terrible for you. Bas a side dish to go with a big green salad with lots of fresh veggies and a vinaigrette dressing a single fried sausage is very good for you. Fats are healthy when accompanied by a lot of fiber and nutrients. Some proteins are better for you than others. Fish being the best.

Once you've figured out a few ideas for meals you'd like to eat during the week start trying to make them. Take your time, and critically practice this technique:
>mise en place
Mise en place will be a complete eye opener for you. It only takes a few times to understand it. Always do this first.

posts.com:
>>18902536
I make a lot of deviled eggs
Like, the egg prices are hurting me
There are only two things that ensure you can peel the egg easily
That you steam them, and you shock them in ice water immediately
When you steam an egg you might want to poke a hole in the air pocket with a safety needle or thumbtack
Rotate the needle, don't push it straight in
Everything else is luck of the draw
I've tried old eggs, dried eggs, warm eggs, cold eggs, none of those matter

One thing to make sure they come out pretty and uniform is to get grade AA
They will also center better if you cook them top end up the top end is the round end with the air pocket
They make egg steamer baskets that are useful when you need to make a ton of eggs

>>18904388
>Photograph better than the painting.
The painting is 400 years old. Significant amounts of the original pigment has faded or discolored, so you are not seeing it as vibrant as it would have been originally.

That said, making photography look like painting is not at all trivial, just as making painting look like photography is not trivial (it's not simply about realism). Also the photograph adds in dynamic elements like the smoke plume and the frontal skull face that change the focus of the original significantly and should be judged on its own merits, so you're free to like it more or less on those terms. But generally you should separate that from your judgement of a medium and an era (which you can like or not like as a whole, but that's different from liking or not liking a specific artwork in said medium from another in a different medium).

>>18902536
>always
either you're doing it wrong or you keep buying eggs that come from the same source and this is just a byproduct of the egg's composition (genetic/diet) and processing.
from my observation, eggs that have this problem have a thick, dry membrane. possibly it's because this keeps water out during the cooking process, the white's surface will also be dry and they become stuck together. whereas you really want there to be a wet interface so that the membrane can slide off after cooking. i'm not sure, scientifically, what could actually affect that in the few minutes of boiling, but i'm sure that's the cause. the rest is decided before you cook so there's not much you can do about it. i've also found that brown eggs are more likely to have thick/tough membranes so i prefer white for boiling. (egg color is genetic also)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18904389
Don't have a picture because it's pretty mundane, but I've made it many times. Grate some cheese fresh - I generally use basic cheddar like Cabot extra sharp, but you can use whatever you want (a lot of people do half cheddar and half American). Don't buy pre-grated cheese, ever. Add it to a bowl with some mayonnaise. Ratio depends on how much cheese you use. Add your pimentos, and some Worcestershire and cayenne. Mash it all together into a spread. Can make it more homogenous in your stand mixer with the paddle attachment.

The seasonings are a matter of taste, so put whatever you like. Try some granulated onion or garlic, hot sauce, whatever. Pimento cheese is one of those things that is infinitely better if you make it at home. It's cheap, easy, and none of the store bought will match it. Another note is to use good mayonnaise. I always use Duke's. Never, ever use Miracle Whip (just save yourself some time and never, ever buy Miracle Whip).

posts.com:
>>18903193
You have milk and sugar. You can make caramel treats.
You can also spike your baked beans with some smokey caramelized sugar (not the same as making milk caramels) if you cook it just right in the pan. This will make them taste warmer and add some calories for what sounds like a survival situation.
Olive oil can be turned into mayonnaise in a pinch by getting an acid and whipping it together until emulsified. If your beans have a tomato based sauce, there's your acid. Mayo is high satiety due to the fat in it, but I won't lie: tomato-olive mayo will be vile unless you have other ingredients you haven't listed like spices. You can then strain a can of beans, mash them into a paste, bruah with soy sauce, and cook that patty in the oven until dry. Apply mayo to the cooked patty.
Caramel energy drink: get your milk really cold, but not frozen. Make the caramel treats above but leave them a liquid. Mix sugar with the cold milk and caramel sauce for a flat shake.

I tend to aire on the spicy side when it comes to ramen. What I used to do when I worked down the road from the Korean store:
>go into store with $20
>buy $20 worth of individual packs of ramen I had not tried before
>try all of them
>decide what I liked from that bunch and took pictures of the package (because lol some of them don't have any engrish text)
>return to store the next time
>repeat process
Some recommendations:
>paldo namja (kicks the shit out of Shin Black imo)
>paldo teumsae
>paldo jjajangmen
>any samyang buldak varieties
>I prefer the cheese kind
>did not like the carbonara or curry
>ottogi sesame with the egg block
>regular shin is fine if you're planning on adding stuff to it or experimenting with the "ramen hacks" that pop up all the time
>I recommend avoiding buying too many cold noodle varieties unless you've verified that you like them already

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18878544
>Any recommendations from /ck/?
make your own
a bulk pack of dried ramen and a can of vegeta only takes 5 minutes + however long it takes to get the water boiling (and costs far less per serve than packets of instant), and you can improve it from there by making stock yourself, using fresh meat or vegetables, a splash of soy sauce or hoisin or some other sauce, aroma oils etc.
It's also less wasteful since you aren't throwing away massive amounts of plastic wrapping, foil sauce packets.
Once you start making your own you'll quickly realise how oily and artificial the instant ramens are.

Yeah but there's no prep time besides having a bowl, some hot water and cutting the packets open. Some already have a bowl and chopsticks included so you don't need anything but the water.

The instant for me means that if if I think about it, it's instantly available.

If you're going for real noodles, by all means ditch the pack and the spices, even make your own noodles if you like. More power to you and I've also done that sometimes.

>>18906904
I don't think I can summarise geopolitics and international business into a 4channel post, but I'll try
Basically they have different costs for inputs to make the ramen and they have separate diplomatic relations with the US results in different trade agreements. Japan has always had an isolationist mentality making many of their items less in supply and more in demand, raising their price. Japan is a small island. China is much larger and connected to greater Asia, Russia, India. They mass produce everything resulting in higher supply, lower demand and therefore lower price
